Situation1: They provide in-depth guidance on a critical task where mistakes could have serious consequences.
Situation2: They occasionally offer comforting words to someone in their congregation who seems troubled.
Story: I sat across from Daniel, my mentee at work, as he anxiously reviewed the details of the project. The stakes were high—one misstep could cost the company dearly. He looked to me for clear, practical advice, expecting me to share every ounce of knowledge I had, to guide him through the technical maze. I felt the weight of responsibility pressing on my shoulders. But as I listened, I noticed the tremor in his voice, the way his eyes darted away. He wasn’t just worried about the task; something deeper was troubling him. As his pastor, I wanted to pause, to offer him comfort, to ask about his heart and his burdens. Yet, I knew that in this moment, he needed a mentor’s precision, not a pastor’s gentle words. The expectations of both roles pulled at me—one demanding clarity and expertise, the other compassion and spiritual care. I hesitated, torn between the urge to guide him through the technical challenge and the call to tend to his spirit. The silence stretched, and I wrestled with which part of myself he needed most right now.
